item.title: High-dimensional quantum key distribution with Qubit-like states
item.author: lukasscarfe@gmail.com (Lukas Scarfe)
item.description: We introduced ‘Fourier-qubits,’ a new class of high-dimensional quantum states that simplify the complexity of secure communication while maintaining high data rates and noise resistance.

item.title: Predicting atmospheric turbulence for secure quantum communications in free space
item.author: lukasscarfe@gmail.com (Lukas Scarfe)
item.description: We developed TAROQQO, a recurrent neural network that predicts atmospheric turbulence strength up to 12 hours in advance to optimize the timing of secure quantum key distribution.

item.title: Fast adaptive optics for high-dimensional quantum communications in turbulent channels
item.author: lukasscarfe@gmail.com (Lukas Scarfe)
item.description: In this work, we showed that the use of a fast adaptive optics system in a high-dimensional quantum key distribution setup allows for secure communications even in the presence of significant noise .

item.title: Orchid Cactus
item.author: lukasscarfe@gmail.com (Lukas Scarfe)
item.description: The Orchid Cactus, known botanically as Epiphyllum, is a captivating tropical plant that defies the standard image of a desert-dwelling succulent. Native to the dense rainforests of Central and South America, these plants are epiphytes, meaning they grow suspended in the jungle canopy, anchoring their roots in the mossy bark and decaying organic matter of tree forks rather than in the soil. Despite their common name, they are not orchids, though they share the same tree-dwelling lifestyle. Their appearance is defined by long, flat, trailing stems that lack the harsh spines of their desert cousins, instead featuring scalloped or wavy edges that gracefully drape from hanging baskets. The true glory of the Orchid Cactus lies in its spectacular, oversized blooms, which can reach up to 10 inches in diameter. These flowers are famous for their neon-bright palette, ranging from fiery reds and electric purples to soft pinks and sunset yellows. Some species, most notably the Epiphyllum oxypetalum or “Queen of the Night,” are strictly nocturnal, unfurling their massive, fragrant white petals only after dusk and withering by dawn—a fleeting, moonlit performance that has gained a cult following among plant enthusiasts. In contrast, many modern hybrids have been bred to bloom during the day, offering a more enduring display of their intricate, multi-petaled geometry throughout the spring and early summer. Cultivating an Orchid Cactus requires a departure from typical cactus care. Because they are “jungle cacti,” they thrive in bright, filtered light rather than harsh, direct sun, which can scorch their delicate stems. They prefer a humid environment and a porous, well-draining potting medium—often a mix of peat, perlite, and orchid bark—to mimic their native arboreal habitat. Unlike desert species, they do not tolerate complete dehydration; they should be watered once the top inch of soil feels dry. A crucial “secret” to securing their legendary blooms is providing a cool, dry rest period during the winter months. By keeping the plant in a cooler room (around 50–55°F) and significantly reducing water for several weeks, you trigger the formation of flower buds that will erupt into a floral masterpiece as the weather warms. With their lush, cascading habit and exotic, jewel-toned blossoms, these plants offer a rewarding blend of structural drama and ethereal beauty.

item.title: Tradescantia Nanouk
item.author: lukasscarfe@gmail.com (Lukas Scarfe)
item.description: The Tradescantia Nanouk, scientifically known as Tradescantia albiflora ‘Nanouk’, is a horticultural masterpiece that has taken the indoor gardening world by storm with its almost ethereal, candy-colored foliage. Developed in the Netherlands in 2012 through a rigorous breeding program, this patented cultivar was specifically designed to be more robust, compact, and vibrantly colored than its older “Spiderwort” or “Inch Plant” relatives. Its leaves are its crowning glory: thick, lance-shaped, and slightly waxy, they feature a stunning variegated pattern of creamy white, sage green, and brilliant fuchsia stripes. Perhaps most striking is the underside of each leaf, which is a solid, vivid magenta that creates a glowing effect when the plant is viewed from below in a hanging basket. Unlike many of its trailing cousins that can become sparse and spindly, the Nanouk has shorter internodes—the space between leaves—which results in a much denser, lusher appearance that looks equally beautiful cascading over a shelf or sitting as a bushy centerpiece on a tabletop.To maintain the high-definition neon hues that make the Nanouk so popular, bright, indirect light is an absolute necessity. While it can tolerate lower light levels, the plant will often “revert” to a plain green to maximize its chlorophyll production, and its stems will stretch out in a “leggy” search for sun, sacrificing its compact charm. A spot near an east- or north-facing window is ideal, providing the energy it needs to produce its small, star-shaped white and yellow flowers that peek out from pink buds during the growing season. Despite its exotic appearance, it is a remarkably resilient plant, though it does have one specific quirk: its fleshy leaves are highly sensitive to standing water. When watering, it is crucial to apply moisture directly to the soil at the base of the plant rather than splashing the foliage, as trapped droplets can lead to unsightly brown spots or fungal rot. In terms of long-term care, the Nanouk thrives in a well-draining potting medium, often enriched with perlite or orchid bark to ensure the roots never sit in stagnant water. It prefers to have the top inch of its soil dry out before receiving a thorough soak. Because it is such a vigorous grower, it may require repotting annually and benefits from regular “pinching”—the practice of snipping off the growing tips to encourage the plant to branch out and stay full. These trimmings need not go to waste, as the Nanouk is famously easy to propagate; a simple stem cutting placed in water or directly into moist soil will typically sprout new roots within a week. This combination of “Insta-worthy” aesthetics and a forgiving, fast-growing nature makes it a perfect bridge plant for beginners looking to move beyond basic greenery into the world of colorful, variegated tropicals.
